report_title: Industry Research: Online Event Ticket Sales in the US
executive_summary: Online ticket sales have experienced a transmutation driven by evolving consumer preferences and technological advancements. Younger consumers enjoy seamless mobile integration, enhancing user experiences through features like QR code-based entrances and real-time updates. This shift has revolutionized ticket sales, making them more accessible and flexible for consumers with unpredictable schedules. Notably, this greater demand for live shows has also propelled ticket prices, often compounded by resellers inflating costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Mobile devices have helped propel online ticket sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Mobile ticketing apps streamline the concert-going experience by integrating QR codes for fast entrances and real-time updates, leading up to the start of an event. Younger consumers who prefer this mobile integration have helped revolutionize the nature of ticket sales.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Ticket Prices Skyrocketed Amid Scarcity Mindset
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: High-demand shows often see ticket prices soar because of genuine demand and resellers. These resellers snap up tickets quickly and then sell them at inflated prices. This practice further exacerbates the cost for fans looking to attend popular events.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Ticketmaster's Dominance Leads to High Service Fees and Long Wait Times
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Ticketmaster's web of exclusivity contracts with artists and venues restricts consumer options, forcing them to go through Ticketmaster for tickets to their favorite artists. Fans encounter malfunctions, long wait times and site crashes, often being shut out of the opportunity to purchase tickets altogether. Ticketmaster's monopoly allows it to mark up ticket prices and charge unreasonable fees without consequences.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: DOJ Files Lawsuit Against Ticket Master
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: On May 23, 2024, the Department of Justice filed an antitrust lawsuit against Ticketmaster and Live Nation Entertainment. The lawsuit claims Live Nation uses its control over concert promotions and ticketing to suppress competition and enforce exclusivity contracts.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumers Will Be Willing To Spend More On Concerts And Sporting Events
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Stronger consumer confidence and disposable income leads to greater spending on recreational activities, including concerts and sporting events. As a result, revenue projections for ticketed events look promising over the next few years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Profit Recovery Will Depend on Young Concert Goers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As these services expand and companies hire more workers, profit will climb slightly over the next five years, but rising wage costs will restrain growth. The popularity of concerts with younger demographics, particularly among Gen Z, will support growth as this demographic gains more buying power, encouraging continued expansion.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Smaller Ticketing Platforms Making Efforts Cater to Fans of Live Events
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Smaller ticketing platforms are making efforts to cater to avid music fans. Companies like Resident Advisor and DICE target electronic music enthusiasts, indie artist fans and residents of metropolitan areas with vibrant music scenes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Event Promotion Will Be Tailored To Individuals
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The future success of ticket sellers will depend on their ability to increase customization, personalization and socialization of ticket sales. With the increasing availability of data collection and analysis, ticket sellers will have a greater understanding of consumers' interests and preferences.

industry_definition: This industry consists of online retailers that sell tickets to live events. Ticketed events include concerts, sporting events, live theater, fairs and festivals. This industry also includes online ticket resellers. But the industry doesn't include sales of tickets at brick-and-mortar locations.
key_trends: Online event ticket sales have a high degree of market share concentration. Exclusivity contracts have contributed to the dominance of Ticketmaster and Live Nation in the industry.
The number of small websites that sell event tickets has been growing steadily. Names like StubHub and Ticketmaster occupy a strong position in the market.

Online ticket sales have fluctuated over the majority of the five years to 2024. The internet has cemented its position as the primary outlet for event ticket purchases, but disruption from the pandemic led to a fall in revenue.
Following the pandemic, online event ticket sales rebounded. The industry will experience continued revenue growth in the coming years.

No company is leading the online event ticket sales market in the US. The industry is composed of many small, independent companies that operate on a local or regional level, but some companies have been able to establish a dominant market position.

market_segmentation.segment: Consumers 34 and Younger are Most Likely to Use Mobile Applications
market_segmentation.segment_description: Adults in these age brackets are more likely to attend live music concerts and sporting events than older people, since this demographic has been the most willing to embrace the growing range of services provided via mobile applications and payment methods.

market_segmentation.segment: Attendance at Sports Events Tends to be High Among Consumers Between 35 and 54
market_segmentation.segment_description: Adults in this age group represent the largest share of the industry's revenue partly because they're more likely to have stable employment to provide a greater amount of disposable income to spend on cultural events. Adults between 35 and 54 years old increased their share of revenue over the past five years, partly due to a greater range of concerts with artists targeting this age demographic.

market_segmentation.segment: Consumers Older Than 55 are Targets for Advertisements From Operators
market_segmentation.segment_description: This age bracket also represents one of the largest demographics for sporting events. Consumers in this age bracket have increased their attendance to live concerts, sporting events and theatrical plays as the overall population has aged. Ticket sales platforms have increasingly targeted this demographic through the advertisement of matinees, a theatre performance that takes place during

products_and_services.product_description: Ticket sales to sporting events includes admission to professional sports franchises and college sports teams. This may include sports like baseball, basketball, football, hockey and soccer, among other individual sports.

This segment includes tickets to live music performances at clubs, music theaters, arenas and amphitheaters and local and regional music festivals. These live music events can have an attendance of fewer than 500 people to more than 100,000 based on the size of the venue.

Online ticket sales for other events include fairs, ethnic festivals, museums and others. This segment also includes public appearances and speeches made by corporate leaders, celebrities, motivational speakers and religious figures and has increased as a percentage of industry revenue recently.

tier_1_suppliers: Performers & Creative Artists in the US
Concert & Event Promotion in the US
Musical Groups & Artists in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The amount of disposable income that a consumer has determines their ability to spend money on event tickets. People are more likely to purchase concert, sporting event or theater admissions as income levels rise and they have more discretionary spending, while sales to events decrease during periods of falling income.

business_locations.location_description: Tech companies and start-ups are located in the West. California alone is home to over 15.0% of industry establishments, in part because of Los Angeles' music roots and the Silicon Valley's prominence as a technological hub. Two of the biggest ticket selling companies are headquartered in the region; Live Nation is based in Beverly Hills, CA, and StubHub is headquartered in San Francisco, CA. California is home to the Silicon Valley region outside of San Francisco, where many multinational tech companies and start-ups alike are based.

Live Events are Popular in the Southeast. The Southeast accounts for the second-greatest share of industry establishments. The Southeast is a major location for club and event promoters, with nearly one-quarter of the company's establishments in the region. Inexpensive rental costs in the region making it a popular area for online ticket event sellers to run their operations.

The Mid-Atlantic is a Prominent Destination for Sports Fans. The Mid-Atlantic has a large population and high income, as well as a strong culture of sports, creating demand for tickets to live sporting events. Tech-based companies are becoming more popular in the region, specifically New York's, though the remainder of the region consists of smaller New England states that don't hold offices of many retailers in this industry.

regulations_points.regulation_title: PRIVACY LAWS AND PROTECTION OF CONSUMER INFORMATION
regulations_points.regulation_description: Since online ticketing platforms store sensitive consumer information in their systems, companies must comply with federal, state and international laws regarding privacy and the storing, sharing, use, disclosure and protection of consumer information and user data.
The legality of secondary ticket reselling varies by state. Many states do not have any laws applicable to secondary ticket reselling, and the ones that do have varying degrees of oversight.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Ticketing platforms must comply with various regulations, like consumer protection, anti-scalping, and privacy laws.
New companies must invest in developing a user-friendly platform, establishing partnerships with event organizers and venues, and implementing payment processing systems.

New entrants need to offer something unique to stand out from the competition. This can be challenging, as many established companies already offer features like mobile ticketing and virtual events, leaving little room for differentiation.

The capital costs required by new entrants are relatively low, but companies must invest in advertising to attract users and build brand awareness. They need to have sufficient capital to cover operational costs, like payment processing fees and customer support.

basis_points.basis_title: Online event ticket sales have a high degree of market share concentration.
basis_points.basis_description: Exclusivity contracts have contributed to the dominance of Ticketmaster and Live Nation in the industry.

basis_points.basis_title: The number of small websites that sell event tickets has been growing steadily.
basis_points.basis_description: Names like StubHub and Ticketmaster occupy a strong position in the market.

concentration_points.concentration_title: There is a high level of competition among ticketing platforms
concentration_points.concentration_description: Online ticket sales platforms face competition from traditional ticketing systems, like box offices and physical ticket outlets, in addition to other online ticketing platforms.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Despite many alternatives, Ticketmaster dominates the market because of its exclusivity agreements with both artists and venues.
concentration_points.concentration_description: Even if one doesn't want to work with Ticketmaster, these contracts make it very difficult for artists and venues to avoid them, intensifying market concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Traditional ticketing systems still have a significant presence in the market and offer competition to online platforms.
concentration_points.concentration_description: Low barriers to entry in the online ticketing industry make it easier for new platforms to enter the market, growing the level of competition.

concentration_points.concentration_title: A diverse range of events and venues require ticketing services
concentration_points.concentration_description: There is a wide variety of events and venues that require ticketing services, including music concerts, sporting events, theaters and conferences.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The diverse range of events and venues means that platforms need to cater to the specific needs and preferences of each event and venue.
concentration_points.concentration_description: Events and venues may choose to work with multiple ticketing platforms to reach a wider audience, further reducing market share concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases costs are high because of exclusivity contracts and expensive agreements.
Costs in this category include payments made to artists, representing agencies and venues for the securing of tickets and entertainment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The capital costs required by new entrants are relatively low, but companies must invest in advertising to attract users and build brand awareness. They need to have sufficient capital to cover operational costs, like payment processing fees and customer support.

volatility_points.volatility_title: DEMAND DEPENDS ON CONSUMER LEISURE TIME AND DISPOSABLE INCOME
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand is influenced by levels of disposable income and general consumer confidence, both of which experienced consistent growth for much of the five-year period. The pandemic created unprecedented levels of disruption for the industry, with revenue plummeting over 40.0% in 2020 alone.

Music concerts and outdoor sporting events report the majority of revenue in the second and third quarters of the year because outdoor venues are used and festivals occur predominantly from April through September. Live events, like concerts and music festivals, are planned months in advance and use collected admission revenue as funding.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Mobile ticketing allows users to purchase, store and display tickets directly on their mobile devices. This innovation eliminates the need for physical tickets and enables event organizers to reduce costs and streamline the ticketing process.
Virtual events and live streaming allow event organizers to sell tickets for events that are accessed remotely, without a need for physical attendance.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Companies sell event tickets online to consumers. Events include concerts, musical and theatrical performances, sporting events and other events, like speeches.

FAQs.question: Do your company's advertising campaigns target a wide range of consumers?
FAQs.answer: Companies attempt to reach the broadest consumer base and target advertisements to different age groups, such as children's concerts and day showings for retirees.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Companies offer competitive salaries to retain talented employees. Engineers and customer service workers are required to keep ticket sellers up and running.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Large companies have acquired smaller, niche ticket sellers to further expand their product offering and customer base. Reducing overhead expenses is an added benefit of their acquisition activity.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Since companies operate completely online, companies have benefited greatly from the sharp rise of online sales.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: The majority of regulations relate to privacy laws and protection of consumers. Companies stay up to date with changes by familiarizing themselves with the Bureau of Consumer Protection.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Online ticket sales have numerous trade associations that seek to promote and grow the marketplace for online event ticket sales, such as The US Ticket Brokers Association.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: The majority of companies require consumers to pay upfront through a credit or debit card and therefore are threatened by consumers not paying on time.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Many companies are subject to seasonal fluctuations in their product offerings. Theater tickets are usually higher during September-April and concert tickets are higher in summer months because of outdoor venue opportunities.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology? What are the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: Larger industry players must take advantage of technology to appeal to performers, increase ticket sales, enhance the consumer experience and provide value-added offerings. Many operators have sold tickets to event streaming services to prevent more substantial losses as in-person gatherings are still highly restricted.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor your major competitors? What features or technology do you offer that your competition does not?
FAQs.answer: It is important to closely monitor the practices and pricing strategies of competitors to ensure they offer competitive pricing options to their customers.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure your website is easy to use for all age demographics? Do you offer a mobile application for purchasing tickets?
FAQs.answer: Ease-of-use is an important design element for online event ticket sellers' websites, mobile applications and digital ticket stubs. Company's product is user/consumer friendly.

FAQs.question: How resilient or sensitive is your service to consumers' leisure time habits? How do you plan to mitigate this threat?
FAQs.answer: The more leisure time Americans have, the more likely they are to occupy their time with events like concerts, sporting events and theater performances.

FAQs.question: What types of advertising does your company use to promote sales? Do you have enough budget saved for advertising expenses?
FAQs.answer: As promotional efforts for a particular event increase, consumers' exposure to the event and their likelihood of purchasing tickets to the event will rise.

FAQs.question: How do you stimulate demand when disposable income levels are low? How can you take advantage of this opportunity?
FAQs.answer: People are more likely to purchase concert, sporting event or theater admissions as incomes rise, while sales to events suffer during periods of falling income.
